attributes.title: Recommendations on patient-facing websites regarding diagnostic imaging for low back, knee and shoulder pain: a scoping review

q1.value: Recommendations on patient-facing websites regarding diagnostic imaging for low back, knee and shoulder pain: a scoping review

q2.value: Andrew Cuff, Thomas Jesson, Professor Lisa Dikomitis, Professor Nadine Foster, Professor Chris Littlewood

q3.value:
•	To identify existing patient-facing websites that may be used as sources of written healthcare information in those with LBP, knee and shoulder pain.

•	To describe and summarise website written content in relation to the use of diagnostic imaging for LBP, knee and shoulder pain.

•	To identify similarities and differences across websites and written information provided in relation to the use of diagnostic imaging for those with LBP, knee and shoulder pain.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: A scoping review will be undertaken, please see attached PDF for full protocol and design.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
A scoping review of patient-facing websites using the Google search engine will be undertaken. 

The inclusion criteria are as follows:

- Patient-facing websites providing written healthcare information related to either LBP, knee or shoulder pain (including advertising websites) that are either based within the United Kingdom (UK) or are NHS affiliated. 

The exclusion criteria are as follows:

- Video-sharing platforms such as YouTube or Google Video or audio links.
- Non-accessible websites.
- Journal articles or websites.

attributes.title: Bayesian Process Tracing in Qualitative Case Research

q1.value: Bayesian Process Tracing in Qualitative Case Research

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Recent work has convincingly illustrated that Bayesian analysis provides a rigorous conceptual and methodological foundation for process tracing and qualitative case research. However, debate has emerged on the extent to which Bayesian analysis can and should be formalized in qualitative research. This task entails assigning numerical values to all probabilities of interest in Bayes’ theorem (i.e., priors on hypotheses and likelihoods for observing the evidence if a given hypothesis is assumed to be true). Advocates argue that formalization can improve analytic transparency, eliminate ambiguity inherent in common language used to describe probabilities, better locate disagreements over interpretation of evidence, and make our reasoning more systematic (Bennett 2015, Humphreys and Jacobs 2015, Rohlfing 2013). Skeptics contend that because probabilities can rarely be objectively quantified in qualitative research, formalization may create a false sense of precision; moreover, the arbitrariness inherent in quantification can undermine the potential gains from systematically aggregating inferences across multiple observations via Bayes’ rule (Fairfield and Charman 2015). In light of this debate, a fundamental and conceptually prior question should be addressed: does training in Bayesian reasoning change how scholars evaluate evidence and assess alternative hypotheses in qualitative case research? Would scholars reach different conclusions given a body of evidence depending on whether they reason informally about which hypothesis provides the best explanation, as is most often done in qualitative research, or instead endeavor to evaluate the relative likelihood of the evidence under one hypothesis compared to a rival, and then update their prior degrees of belief in those hypotheses using Bayes’ theorem? We have designed an experiment that will begin to address these questions, to be conducted in the summer of 2016 with roughly 80 political science graduate students.

q16.value: The primary variable of interest is the Weight of Evidence (WOE), which is proportional to log [ P ( E | H1 ) / P ( E | H2 ) ] for a particular piece of information E given two rival hypotheses H1 and H2. The WOE indicates how to update log-odds for the two hypotheses in light of the evidence. The WOE can be elicited explicitly on the post-test for treatment-group students who have received training in Bayesian probability, and indirectly on the pre-tests and control group post-test. Our experimental hypotheses are as follows: H1: Bayesian training should lead students to evaluate evidence differently than students in the control group, such that (post-test WOE – pre-test WOE) should differ on average for the treatment and control groups. H2: Bayesian training should lead students to report weights of evidence that are closer to the investigators’ expert assessments of reasonable conclusions for each case scenario on the post-test. H3a: Bayesian training should help build inter-personal consensus on weights of evidence, such that the variance in the post-test WOE is smaller for the treatment group compared to the control group. H3b: A regression of post-test WOE plotted against pre-test WOE should tend toward a horizontal line for the treatment group, as they come to a reasonable consensus despite pre-treatment differences, while the control group should tend closer to a 45 degree line reflecting that they remain more “set in their ways” or have had their thinking less changed by the non-Bayesian training. H4: The order in which pieces of evidence are presented on the pre-test should matter for how students evaluate the evidence, such that the mean aggregate WOE will differ between the two groups.

q17.value: Participants will be divided into a treatment group (to receive Bayesian training) and control group (to receive non-Bayesian training) via blocked random assignment, based on results from a brief preliminary survey that assesses overall educational attainment as well as experience with mathematics and statistics courses. The treatment group will receive approximately 4 hours of training in Bayesian probability and applications to case study research, plus overnight homework exercises, while the control group will receive an equivalent amount of non-Bayesian process-tracing training. We will look for differences in inferences across the treatment and control groups. In addition, all participants will be randomly assigned to one of two sub-groups, which will receive different versions of the pre-test. These pre-tests will differ only in the order of the pieces of evidence presented for one of the two case scenarios. Because we are interested in the possible effects of Bayesian training, it is natural to adopt and apply Bayesian analysis to assess these hypotheses, in addition to employing more standard frequentist statistical methodology. Bayesian methods enjoy a number of advantages, particularly when testing multiple hypotheses, but the attached pre-analysis plan focuses on the frequentist analysis.

q3.value:
All prior research has utilized bi-directionally related stimuli (["king" and "queen"] OR ["knee-bone" and "knee-bend"]), so the direction of remindings has not been tested.  Spreading activation models uniquely suggest that the direction of association between related episodes should not influence mnemonic benefits of reminding.  P1s (the item presented earlier in the list) can proactively boost memory for later related P2s (the item presented later in the list) and P2s can retroactively boost memory for earlier related P1s.  In contrast, three other reminding models suggest that remindings occur only when P2 points back toward the earlier P1 (P1's pro-active association towards P2 is irrelevant to remindings).  

Experiment 1 is novel because it will utilize unidirectionally related word pairs to assess the impact of pro-active and retro-active associations on memory ("airport" is associated to "plane", but "plane" is not associated to "airport", according to South Florida Free Association Norms).  Prior research examining directed forgetting hints that remindings only happen when related pairs point backwards towards earlier studied items, and this experiment will directly test that hypothesis.

q4.value:
P2s that point back to P1s will enhance free recall of P1s.
P1s that point forward to P2s will not enhance free recall of P1s.

P2s that point back to P1s will prompt greater recall of P1s BEFORE associated P2s than other conditions.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value:
Learners will study a list of unidirectionally associated word pairs one at a time.  Half of the word pairs will be arranged such that P1→ P2 ("airport" shown earlier in the list than "plane") and half as P1←P2 ("plane" shown earlier in the list than "airport").  

Learners will go through 2 study/test cycles.  In each study/test cycle, they will study a list of 52 words (24 word pairs and 4 single items).  Of the 24 word pairs, they will be equally divided among forward-associated pairs, backward-associated pairs, and unrelated pairs.  Words will be displayed one at a time for 5 seconds each.  Learners will take a free recall test after study; recall of P1s will be compared across the temporal ordering conditions and to the unrelated condition using 3 paired t-tests.  Spreading activation predicts equal memory regardless of temporal ordering, while the three other models suggest that only the P1←P2 condition should boost memory compared to the control condition.

q9.value: Word pairs will be randomly assigned to condition and randomly ordered during study, with the restriction that each condition is displayed an equal number of times before a condition is repeated.

question.value: association direction (forward, backward, unrelated)
free recall

A:  We will compare recall of P1 between the three conditions using an ANOVA.
Follow-up paired samples t-tests will test for differences in recall of P1 between conditions
1. backward vs. forward 
2. backward vs. unrelated
3. forward vs. unrelated

B:  While not central to our main hypotheses, we will repeat analysis A with recall of P2s.

C:  We will also compare the output order for pairs in which both P1 and P2 were recalled.
In backward, what proportion of P1s were recalled before their related P2?
In forward, what proportion of P1s were recalled before their related P2?  
In unrelated, what proportion of P1s were recalled before their associated P2?  
We will test whether the percent of P1s recalled before P2s depends upon the condition using an ANOVA and paired t-tests, as described above.

attributes.title: Revisión sistemática de literatura sobre la eficacia y seguridad de las monoterapias de fexofenadina y montelukast, y la terapia de montelukast en combinación con fexofenadina u otros antihistamínicos de segunda generación para el tratamiento de la rinitis alérgica

summary.value:
Objetivo: evaluar la eficacia y seguridad de las monoterapias de fexofenadina y montelukast, y la terapia de montelukast en combinación con fexofenadina u otros antihistamínicos de segunda generación para el tratamiento de la rinitis alérgica. 
Material y métodos: revisión sistemática de literatura acorde a las pautas propuestas en el Manual Cochrane para Revisiones Sistemáticas de Intervenciones a partir de datos de estudios publicados del 01 de enero de 2009 al 31 de diciembre de 2018. 
Resultados: en los estudios revisados la evaluación de eficacia se realizó mediante síntomas individuales como la rinorrea; mientras que, en otros estudios, se utilizaron los puntajes totales o compuestos de síntomas nasales. La seguridad se evaluó mediante la identificación de eventos adversos (EA) reportados tras la aplicación de las intervenciones. Se analizó la incidencia de EA de fexofenadina y montelukast como monoterapias, y montelukast solo o en combinación con fexofenadina u otros antihistamínicos de segunda generación.

attributes.title: The social construction of kinds: A developmental comparison of animals, artifacts, and

summary.value:
Replication of Study 2 with methodological improvements.

Younger children were unexpectedly at ~50% for all conditions, which produced a counter-intuitive developmental trajectory. The most plausible explanation is that the wording of the task was confusing to young children because there was no training phase and because of the complexity of the vignette. For example, by positioning the task on Vawnsie Island, it may not have been clear whether the Vawnsies used words the same way we do, whether they understood what "turtles" and "artists" were. The idea of a turtle "acting like a frog" may have led children to think the animals had changed their behaviors rather than merely changing their role on the island. We added a training phase and we made the vignettes and test question dramatically simpler. 

Everything else was the same.

Training phase: 
"The United States is the name of the country we live in.
 
We are going to imagine that everyone in the United States decides to change something. Sometimes, we can choose to change the way things are, just by changing our minds. But, sometimes we can't change the way things are - even if we want to. 
 
You're going to help me figure out when people can change things just by saying so. And when we can't change things just by saying so. 

Let's start: 
In the United States, children aren't allowed to wear pajamas to school every single day. But imagine that everyone decided that it was okay now! 
Could it really change to be okay? [Correct answer: Yes. Children corrected if wrong.]

In the United States, children aren't allowed to hit people and make them cry. But imagine that everyone decided that it was okay now! 
Could it really change to be okay? [Correct answer: No. Children corrected if wrong.]

So we can change whether its okay to wear pajamas to school but we can't change whether its okay to hit someone!"

New Vignette and test question: (example)
"In the United States, we have turtles and frogs - like in ponds.

Look at this on the left - it’s a turtle!  Imagine that everyone decides that it should change into a frog now! Could it really change into a frog?"

q1.value: Social Media Use and Psychological Functioning in Emerging Adults

q3.value: Data will be collected regarding the relation of lesbian, gay and bisexual (LGB) and heterosexual emerging adults' social media use and mental health, including psychological well-being, anxiety symptoms and depression symptoms. Previous research suggests there are two main types of social media use: active use and passive use. This past research suggests that active social media use may improve a user's mental health, while passive social media use may harm a user's mental health. There is a need to collect information on the impact of social media use in diverse populations, such as the LGB community. Data will also be collected from emerging adults who identify as heterosexual in order to develop a comparison group. Research will be collected through online self-report surveys completed by emerging adults who identify as LGB and who use social media. Data will be collected regarding their demographic information, social media use style (active or passive), psychological well-being, depression, worry and anxiety levels.

q4.value:
1. In LGB emerging adults, passive social media use will be positively related to mental health symptoms, including depression and anxiety.
2. In LGB emerging adults, passive social will be negatively related to psychological well-being.
3. In LGB emerging adults individuals, active social media use will be negatively related to mental health symptoms, including depression and anxiety.
4. In LGB emerging adults, active social media will be positively associated with psychological well-being.
5. In LGB emerging adults, active social media use will be negatively associated with passive social media use.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
The present study will use a correlational research strategy with a cross-sectional design to examine associations between active social media use, passive social media use, psychological well-being, depression symptoms, and anxiety symptoms in a sample of emerging adults who identify as LGB. All data will be obtained from on-line self-report questionnaires. Based on a power analysis (see Data Analysis section below), the target sample size is approximately 85 emerging adults who identify as LGB and 85 emerging adults who identify as heterosexual. Data collection will continue until June 1, 2020 and all participants who meet study criteria who have completed the surveys will be included in the study, even if this number exceeds 85. The target population will be emerging adults who identified as LGB and engaged in some kind of social media use, regardless of the platform(s) they utilize. Participants who do not respond to every question or who do not complete the questionnaire in its entirety will be excluded from the study. In order to calculate the means and standard deviations of the variables, descriptive statistics will be utilized. The average level of psychological well-being, anxiety symptoms, worry symptoms and depression symptoms will be reported along with the standard deviation of each variable. A Pearson correlation will be utilized in order to test each hypothesis and the analyses conducted in order to determine if statistical test assumptions were met will include a visual inspection of the data to ensure a linear relation exists for all of the variables. Three multiple regression analyses will be conducted in order to examine the exploratory analyses. For the exploratory regression analyses, assumptions include examining collinearity to ensure there is not a strong correlation between active and passive use. The residuals will also be plotted in order to ensure that normal distribution occurs. If assumptions are violated, then a robust regression will be conducted, and bootstrapping will be adjusted for the coefficients.
A power analysis was conducted to ascertain the number of participants needed to achieve a power level of .80, with an alpha level of .05 for small, medium, and large effect sizes. The analysis revealed that 29 participants would be needed to detect a small effect size, r2 = 1%, 85 for a medium effect, r2 = 9%, and 782 for a large effect, r2 = 25%. Thus, the study sample was large enough to detect a medium effect size for each predictor above.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Based on a power analysis, the target sample size is approximately 85 emerging adults who identify as LGB and 85 emerging adults who identify as heterosexual. Data collection will continue until June 1, 2020 and all participants who meet study criteria who have completed the surveys will be included in the study, even if this number exceeds 85. The target population was emerging adults who identified as LGB and emerging adults who identified as heterosexual and engaged in some kind of social media use, regardless of the platform(s) they utilize. Participants who do not respond to every question or who did not complete the questionnaire in its entirety were excluded from the study. Inclusion criteria for this study are emerging adults, which includes individuals ages 18 through 29. Individuals below and above this age range will be excluded. The individuals included will be self-identified as LGB or heterosexual and endorse “yes” to a question regarding their use of social media sites. The type of sampling utilized in order to achieve this sample type will be convenience sampling. A non-random sample of individuals self-selected themselves to fill out the online survey they received. Information about the study and a link to the online questionnaires were shared with LGBTQ+ offices and organizations on college campuses via email and in person. Surveys will also be shared via email with LGBTQ+ offices and organizations on college campuses outside of the Baltimore area. Surveys were asked to be shared with those who identify as LGB and use social media. The survey link will also shared with LGBTQ+ listservs and posted on LGBTQ+ community websites. Once disseminated, viewers of the survey will be asked to share the survey with their friends or family members who identify as LGB and use social media. The survey will also be distributed through Loyola's SONA participant pool.

q15.value: Data collection will be terminated by June 2020 unless the 85 target sample size is not achieved.

question.value: Scores from a modified version of the Passive and Active Facebook Use Measure (PAUM) (Gerson et al., 2017) will be used to assess passive and active social media use in the current study. Scores from the Psychological Well-being Scale, Shortened 18-Item Version (Ryff, Keyes & Hughes, 2003) will be used to assess psychological well-being in the present study. Scores from the Generalized Anxiety Disorder 7-item scale (GAD-7; Spitzer, Kroenke, Williams, & Lowe, 2006), which assesses symptoms of Generalized Anxiety Disorder within the past two weeks (Spitzer et al., 2006), will be used to assess anxiety symptoms in the present study. Because there is some preliminary evidence to suggest that the GAD-7 is more discriminating at high levels of worry and less discriminating at lower levels of worry (Jordan, Shedden-Mora, & Lowe, 2017) anxiety symptoms will also be assessed by the ultra brief version of the Penn State Worry Questionnaire (PSWQ-3). Scores from the Patient Health Questionnaire (Kroenke, Spitzer, & Williams, 2001), a brief depression measure that inquires about symptoms of Major Depressive Disorder within the past two weeks (Kroenke, Spitzer, & Williams, 2001), will be used to assess depressive symptoms in the current study.

In order to calculate the means and standard deviations of the variables, descriptive statistics will be utilized. The average level of psychological well-being, anxiety symptoms, worry symptoms and depression symptoms will be reported along with the standard deviation of each variable. A Pearson correlation will be utilized in order to test each hypothesis and the analyses conducted in order to determine if statistical test assumptions were met will include a visual inspection of the data to ensure a linear relation exists for all of the variables. Three multiple regression analyses will be conducted in order to examine the exploratory analyses. For

A power analysis was conducted to ascertain the number of participants needed to achieve a power level of .80, with an alpha level of .05 for small, medium, and large effect sizes. The analysis revealed that 29 participants would be needed to detect a small effect size, r2 = 1%, 85 for a medium effect, r2 = 9%, and 782 for a large effect, r2 = 25%. Thus, the study sample was large enough to detect a medium effect size for each predictor above.

3. Examine whether or not active social media use predicts psychological well-being, depression symptoms, or anxiety symptoms above and beyond passive social media use.

attributes.title: Fast errors and evaluative race priming. A preregistration of a study using Project Implicit research pool data

q1.value: Fast errors and evaluative race priming. A preregistration of a study using Project Implicit research pool data

q3.value:
The research build on recent work reported by Tipples and Lupton (submitted) that set out to isolate the rapid influence of face sex on speeded angry and happy face recognition using  Bayesian Generalized Linear Mixed Effects Modelling of both RTs as a function of accuracy and participant sex and  accuracy rates as a function of RT and participant sex. The key results were that for female participants, the effects of face sex operate quickly as reflected in 2 statistical patterns 1) modulation the first moment of the ex-Gaussian and 2) fast errors. Finally, analysing the RT-accuracy relationship helped identify an unexpected effect – the fast-error effect was smallest for both male and female participants responding to in-group positive faces (e.g., male-happy faces for male participants). Overall, the results are consistent with the idea that for female participants, stereotypes are automatically activated on seeing face sex. Results also highlight the value of both distributional analyses and studying the RT-accuracy relationship.   
Here, I want to establish whether the results reported by Tipples and Lupton (submitted) generalize to other related effects such as automatic activation of evaluative associations for race recorded using the evaluative priming task  (Axt, Bar-Anan,& Vianello, 2019). I will test this idea using the same statistical tools namely Bayesian Generalized Linear Mixed Effects Modelling of both RTs and accuracy. The prediction is that there will be fast-errors for evaluatively incongruent prime-target pairs (e.g., black-good) compared to evaluatively congruent (black-bad) prime-target pairs

q4.value:
For the evaluative priming task, 

Question 1a - To what extent do participants make fast-errors in the form of faster RTs on error compared to correct trials  and relatedly, (Question 2a) - To what extent do participants respond inaccurately with increased speed 
Question 1b – Accuracy will decrease with response speed to a greater extent for evaluatively incongruent prime-target pairs (e.g., black-good) compared to evaluatively congruent (black-bad) prime-target pairs 

Question 2b – Do errors increase with response speed to a greater extent for evaluatively incongruent prime-target pairs (e.g., black-good) compared to evaluatively congruent (black-bad) prime-target pairs
Question 2b - To what extent do reductions in accuracy with speed increase for evaluatively incongruent prime-target pairs (e.g., black-good) compared to evaluatively congruent (black-bad) prime-target pairs.

Exploratory - To what extent does the fast-error effect increase or decrease in magnitude with 1) explicit ratings of preference for White vs Black people and 2) explicit liking ratings for White vs Black people (liking index) and 3) explicit valence ratings for White vs Black people (Thermometer index).

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Within subjects "evaluative congruence" with 2 levels (incongruent, congruent) - evaluatively incongruent prime-target pairs (e.g., black-good) compared to evaluatively congruent (black-bad) prime-target pairs. Trial level accuracy rates (within subjects) will be included as a predictor for analyses of RT as a dependent variable and "RT bin" will be a covariate (within subjects or level 1)  for analyses of accuracy rates. Between subject idecises of liking, preference and valence will also be included in the regression models.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: A5: I will using existing research data (Axt, Bar-Anan,& Vianello, 2019) in which the authors  sampled 4,500 participants from the Project Implicit research pool. Participants in the sample completed multiple measures including the Evaluative Priming Task. Full details of the study (https://osf.io/7tcwa/. Participants will be excluded if more than 40% of trials were errors (Bar-Anan & Nosek, 2014; 2.9% of EPT scores) . Sample size is expected to be 1,353 (based on Table 1 Axt, Bar-Anan, & Vianello, 2019).

question.value: The data were collected as part of the Project Implicit research pool. The data can be accessed by going to the following link https://osf.io/7tcwa/

q13.value: Sample size is expected to be 1,353 (based on Table 1 Axt, Bar-Anan, & Vianello, 2019).

question.value: Evaluative congruence. The primes were either congruent with stereotypical evaluations (e.g., a black face and bad target word) or incongruent for example, a white face and bad word. We will create a congruency variable by averaging over congruent prime target pairs (black-bad and white-good) and incongruent pairs (e.g., white-bad and black-good)

Yes, 3 self-report variables: 1) explicit ratings of preference for White vs Black people and 2) explicit liking ratings for White vs Black people (liking index) and 3) explicit valence ratings for White vs Black people (Thermometer index).   For the analyses of accuracy rats we will include RT bin as the treatment coded predictor variable. The variable RT bin will be created by sorting RTs for both correct and incorrect responses  into percentiles (0–20, 20–40, 40–60, 60–80, 80–100%) for each participant and congruence condition.

All hypotheses will be tested using Generalized Linear Mixed Effects Modelling 

Questions 1a and 1b will be tested by fitting raw RTs to the first moment (mu) of the ex-Gaussian with by-subject intercepts for tau. For RT model, congruency (incongruent = 1 and congruent = 0) and accuracy (1= correct, 0 = error) will be the independent variables. For RTs, models will include an accuracy X congruency interaction term and conditional main effects. Further models will add the slope for composite indices of explicit preference, liking and valence. 

Questions 2a and 2b will be tested using a single Generalized Linear Mixed Effects model with number of correct responses as the dependent variable and both congruency (incongruent = 1 and congruent = 0) and RT bin as the treatment coded predictor variables. The variable RT bin will be created by sorting RTs for both correct and incorrect responses  into percentiles (0–20, 20–40, 40–60, 60–80, 80–100%) for each participant and congruency condition. The final model will include β congruency (1=incongruent) X RT bin (5) interaction term and all conditional effects. For the variable RT Bin the fastest RTs (0–20 bin) will serve as the intercept . To test the hypothesis that congruency effects for accuracy rates vary as a function of RT, I will using sliding or repeated contrasts for the variable RT bin. Specifically, I will estimate a slope for differences in RT bin for adjacent (increasing) RT bins (e.g., contrast 1: 0–20 vs 20–40; contrast 2: 20–40 vs 40-60 etc)  

For all models I will attempt to fit the maximum random effects structure by starting with a fully-crossed slope, intercept and intercept-slope correlation. As this may not be possible using maximum likelihood, model fitting will proceed by dropping the intercept-slope correlation.

q25.value:
Below I have specified a Bayesian Analysis. If this is not feasible (because the dataset is very large and computation times may be very long) I will attempt model fitting using Maximum Likelihood and use Frequentist statistical decision making with alpha set to p<.01 

A20:  For the analyses of RTs a minimum effect size of 10 milliseconds with the 95% Highest Density Interval for RTs extending less than 50 milliseconds. For the accuracy model, the smallest effect of interest is a change in the Odds of greater than 1.05 (where 1  indicates a practically equivalent proportion of error and correct responses). Also for accuracy rates  we expect the 95% Highest Density Interval for the beta coefficients to be narrow – a change in the log Odds of less than 1.8 (corresponding to changing probability of less than 35%)  

Q21: Present the statistical power available to detect the predicted effect size(s) or the smallest effect size(s) of interest. Use the sample size after updating for missing data and outliers.  

A21: The sample size after updating for missing data and outliers is over 1300 participants. This is very large and likely to produce narrow credible intervals. I am estimating Bayesian Highest Density Intervals and therefore, I am less concerned about the long-term frequency of rejecting the null in multiple experiments carried out in the future. Instead, I will focus on the probability of the hypothesis conditioned on the conditional density of the data given the parameters and the priors for the model. 

Q22: What criteria will you use to make inferences? Describe the information you will use (e.g. specify the p-values, effect sizes, confidence intervals, Bayes factors, specific model fit indices), as well as cut-off criteria, where appropriate. Will you be using one- or two-tailed tests for each of your analyses? If you are comparing multiple conditions or testing multiple hypotheses, will you account for this, and if so, how? 

A22: The 95% Highest Density Intervals will exclude the value zero. Greater theoretical weight will be placed on estimates if they are precise — the 95% Highest Density Interval covers a relatively narrow region. 

Q23: What will you do should your data violate assumptions, your model not converge, or some other analytic problem arises? 

A23: I will examine the distribution of the data by fitting the data averaged over all predictor variables to various candidate distributions (e.g., the ex-Gaussian is the default for RT analyses) using maximum likelihood estimation. I also will consider applying different outlier criteria for reaction times. For example, reaction times will be removed if they are either 2.5×IQR or more above the third quartile or 2.5×IQR or more below the first quartile of the entire distribution of (log-transformed) RTs. If skew remains after this I will consider using a less conservative criteria namely Tukey’s hinges - 1.5×IQR rather than 2.5xIQR

Also for accuracy rates  we expect the 95% Highest Density Interval for the beta coefficients to be narrow – a change in the log Odds of less than 1.8 (corresponding to changing probability of less than 35%)  

Q21: Present the statistical power available to detect the predicted effect size(s) or the smallest effect size(s) of interest. Use the sample size after updating for missing data and outliers.  

A21: The sample size after updating for missing data and outliers is over 1300 participants. This is very large and likely to produce narrow credible intervals. I am estimating Bayesian Highest Density Intervals and therefore, I am less concerned about the long-term frequency of rejecting the null in multiple experiments carried out in the future. Instead, I will focus on the probability of the hypothesis conditioned on the conditional density of the data given the parameters and the priors for the model. 

Q22: What criteria will you use to make inferences? Describe the information you will use (e.g. specify the p-values, effect sizes, confidence intervals, Bayes factors, specific model fit indices), as well as cut-off criteria, where appropriate. Will you be using one- or two-tailed tests for each of your analyses? If you are comparing multiple conditions or testing multiple hypotheses, will you account for this, and if so, how? 

A22: The 95% Highest Density Intervals will exclude the value zero. Greater theoretical weight will be placed on estimates if they are precise — the 95% Highest Density Interval covers a relatively narrow region. 

Q23: What will you do should your data violate assumptions, your model not converge, or some other analytic problem arises? 

A23: I will examine the distribution of the data by fitting the data averaged over all predictor variables to various candidate distributions (e.g., the ex-Gaussian is the default for RT analyses) using maximum likelihood estimation. I also will consider applying different outlier criteria for reaction times. For example, reaction times will be removed if they are either 2.5×IQR or more above the third quartile or 2.5×IQR or more below the first quartile of the entire distribution of (log-transformed) RTs. If skew remains after this I will consider using a less conservative criteria namely Tukey’s hinges - 1.5×IQR rather than 2.5xIQR
registration_responses.q8.question: Within subjects "evaluative congruence" with 2 levels (incongruent, congruent) - evaluatively incongruent prime-target pairs (e.g., black-good) compared to evaluatively congruent (black-bad) prime-target pairs. Trial level accuracy rates (within subjects) will be included as a predictor for analyses of RT as a dependent variable and "RT bin" will be a covariate (within subjects or level 1)  for analyses of accuracy rates. Between subject idecises of liking, preference and valence will also be included in the regression models.
registration_responses.q12.question: The data were collected as part of the Project Implicit research pool. The data can be accessed by going to the following link https://osf.io/7tcwa/
registration_responses.q16.question: Evaluative congruence. The primes were either congruent with stereotypical evaluations (e.g., a black face and bad target word) or incongruent for example, a white face and bad word. We will create a congruency variable by averaging over congruent prime target pairs (black-bad and white-good) and incongruent pairs (e.g., white-bad and black-good)
registration_responses.q17.question: Yes, 3 self-report variables: 1) explicit ratings of preference for White vs Black people and 2) explicit liking ratings for White vs Black people (liking index) and 3) explicit valence ratings for White vs Black people (Thermometer index).   For the analyses of accuracy rats we will include RT bin as the treatment coded predictor variable. The variable RT bin will be created by sorting RTs for both correct and incorrect responses  into percentiles (0–20, 20–40, 40–60, 60–80, 80–100%) for each participant and congruence condition.
registration_responses.q19.question:
All hypotheses will be tested using Generalized Linear Mixed Effects Modelling 

Questions 1a and 1b will be tested by fitting raw RTs to the first moment (mu) of the ex-Gaussian with by-subject intercepts for tau. For RT model, congruency (incongruent = 1 and congruent = 0) and accuracy (1= correct, 0 = error) will be the independent variables. For RTs, models will include an accuracy X congruency interaction term and conditional main effects. Further models will add the slope for composite indices of explicit preference, liking and valence. 

Questions 2a and 2b will be tested using a single Generalized Linear Mixed Effects model with number of correct responses as the dependent variable and both congruency (incongruent = 1 and congruent = 0) and RT bin as the treatment coded predictor variables. The variable RT bin will be created by sorting RTs for both correct and incorrect responses  into percentiles (0–20, 20–40, 40–60, 60–80, 80–100%) for each participant and congruency condition. The final model will include β congruency (1=incongruent) X RT bin (5) interaction term and all conditional effects. For the variable RT Bin the fastest RTs (0–20 bin) will serve as the intercept . To test the hypothesis that congruency effects for accuracy rates vary as a function of RT, I will using sliding or repeated contrasts for the variable RT bin. Specifically, I will estimate a slope for differences in RT bin for adjacent (increasing) RT bins (e.g., contrast 1: 0–20 vs 20–40; contrast 2: 20–40 vs 40-60 etc)  

For all models I will attempt to fit the maximum random effects structure by starting with a fully-crossed slope, intercept and intercept-slope correlation. As this may not be possible using maximum likelihood, model fitting will proceed by dropping the intercept-slope correlation.

attributes.title: Dark Triad and Intimate Partner Violence

q1.value: Examination of the each Dark Triad construct as they relate to the perpetration and victimization of Intimate Partner Violence

q3.value:
Prior research has observed that there is a relationship between individual aspects of the Dark Triad (narcissism, psychopathy, and Machiavellianism) and violence/aggression, yet little is currently known on the Dark Triad’s connection to physical, psychological, and emotional partner abuse. Intimate partner violence (IPV) is widespread across many different cultures and has serious consequences for its victims, be it physical, social, emotional, or economic. The prevalence of IPV, along with the potential damage it poses, makes it a major public health issue that warrants further research. Learning more about this topic can improve future risk assessment tools and treatment methods for the perpetrators of IPV.
The most recent study on Dark Triad and IPV was conducted by Carton & Egan (2017). Our goal is to expand on this study while addressing some of the limitations.  We will also be using full measures of each personality construct instead of relying on the short dark triad (SD3). We also aim to assess the incremental effects of the Dark Triad over and above general personality traits. Finally, we will not be assessing all Dark Triad constructs in the same model given recent criticisms about this level of partialing (e.g., Sleep et al., 2017).

q4.value:
Question 1: What is the relationship between the FFM of personality and both the perpetration and victimization of Intimate Partner Violence (IPV), while controlling for age and gender?
Hypothesis 1: After controlling for gender and age, agreeableness will be significantly and negatively related to both the perpetration and victimization of IPV (measured by the CTS2S). This hypothesis is based on the findings from Carton and Egan (2017).

Question 2: What is the relationship between psychopathy and both the perpetration and victimization of Intimate Partner Violence (IPV), while controlling for age, gender, and the FFM?
Hypothesis 2: Psychopathy will be significantly related to both the perpetration and victimization of IPV.  More specifically, the affective facet will show the largest relationships with IPV.

Question 3: What is the relationship between narcissism and both the perpetration and victimization of Intimate Partner Violence (IPV), while controlling for age, gender, and the FFM?
Hypothesis 3: Narcissism will be significantly related to both the perpetration and victimization of IPV.

Question 4: What is the relationship between Machiavellianism and both the perpetration and victimization of Intimate Partner Violence (IPV), while controlling for age, gender, and the FFM?
Hypothesis: Given that several studies have linked Machiavellianism to sexual coercion (e.g., Jonason & Kavanagh, 2010) and that others have not found relationships between Machiavellianism and IPV (e.g., Kiire, 2017) and that Carton and Egan did not find relationships between MACH and the CTS, it was predicted that the facets of agency and planfulness of the FFMI would not be related to the perpetration or victimization of IPV. The antagonism facet, however, was predicted to be related to perpetration and victimization of IPV.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Study Design
Survey design. Participants completed all of the measures at the same time. After providing informed consent and demographics, the following scales were presented in random order: Self-Report Psychopathy Scale: 4 Short Form (SRP:4SF; Neumann & Hare, 2016); Five Factor Machiavellianism Inventory (FFMI; Collison et al., 2018); Narcissistic Personality Inventory – 16 (NPI-16; Raskin & Terry, 1988); The Big Five Inventory (BFI; John & Srivastava, 1999). Participants then completed the Revised Conflict Tactics Scale short form (CTS2S; Straus & Douglas, 2004).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants are recruited online from Qualtrics. Study participation will be advertised on Qualtrics, those interested will access a Qualtrics participation invitation. No identifying participant data will be collected. Qualtrics recruits participants from a number of different sources. Please see the statement below:
“ Participants are recruited from various sources, including website intercept recruitment, member referrals, targeted email lists, gaming sites, customer loyalty web portals, permission-based networks, and social media, etc. Consumer panel members’ names, addresses, and dates of birth are typically validated via third party verification measures prior to joining
The standard compensation for Qualtrics participants is between $0.80 to $2.00 depending on how they were recruited. Importantly, any eligible participant who consents to the study will be compensated the stated amount regardless of how many questions they answer. Participants can stop the study at any time, skip any questions, and still receive the full compensation amount.  Please see statement below provided by Qualtrics: 

“Our panelists join from a variety of sources. They may be airline customers who chose to join in reward for SkyMiles, retail customers who opted in to get points at their favourite retail outlet, or general consumers who participate for cash or gift cards, etc. When participants are invited to take the survey they are informed what they will be compensated. Because each respondent is compensated differently, it would be inappropriate to inform how much they will be compensated in the cover letter. Instead, we recommend including verbiage among the lines of “You will be compensated the amount you agreed upon before you entered into the survey.”

The following criteria were necessary to be eligible for the study: 1) at least 18 years of age or older; 2) citizen of Canada or the US; 3) must have a current or past romantic relationship that has lasted at least 12 months. Qualtrics project managers provide the following additional data cleaning (respondents are filtered out and not counted towards the final sample size): 1) anyone failing the attention check (i.e., “The following question is to ensure that the survey software is working correctly, please choose 3”; 2) straight liners; 3) respondents with a response time that is too fast; 4) non-completers.

q14.value:
We used G*Power 3.1.9.4 (Faul, Erdfelder, Lang, & Buchner, 2007) to determine the required sample size needed to detect significant effects using an alpha of .03 (adjusted because we were testing multiple models) and 80% power for a multiple linear regression (fixed-model; R2 increase). In order to determine the appropriate effect size, we used effects determined by Carton and Egan (2017; see Table 4, p. 87). Variance explained by a special effect was therefore set at .10 and the residual variance at .58. Inputting these numbers into G*Power gave an expected effect size of .17. We planned to test four separate models:

Model 1: Controls (n = 2; gender and age) + FFM (n = 5; neuroticism, agreeableness, conscientiousness, extraversion, and openness)
Model 2: Controls (n = 2) + FFM (n = 5) + SRP4:SF facets (n = 4; interpersonal, affective, lifestyle, antisocial)
Model 3: Controls (n = 2) + FFM (n = 5) + NPI-16 total (n = 1)
Model 4: Controls (n = 2) + FFM (n = 5) + FFMI factors (n = 3; antagonism, agency, and planfulness)

The total number of tested predictors therefore ranged from 5 (model 1) to 9 (model 2). The total number of predictors ranged from 7 (model 1) to 11 (model 2). The largest sample size needed for the model with the largest number of predictors (model 2) was therefore 112. We decided to collect a total sample of 150.

question.value: None

Participants will complete the study entirely online using the Qualtrics survey program. The survey will cover three components: (1) relationship + demographics; (2) personality; and (3) conflict tactics.

Relationship + Demographics 
Brief Demographic Questionnaire: Will obtain information regarding a participant’s relationship status, age, gender, ethnic background, level of education, employment status, and whether or not they have been convicted of a criminal offence.

Personality 
1. Self-Report Psychopathy Scale – 4 Short Form (SRP: 4SF; Paulhus, Neumann & Hare, 2016): The SRP-SF is a shortened version of the Self-Report Psychopathy Scale – 4 (SRP-4), which has been used to assess psychopathy in non-CJS populations. It uses a five-point Likert scale that ranges from “Strongly disagree” to “Strongly agree”. The SRP-SF contains 29 items, while the SRP-4 has 64 items. The SRP-4 uses the same two-factor, four-facet model as the Hare Psychopathy Checklist – Revised (PCL-R). 

2. Five Factor Machiavellianism Inventory (FFMI; Collison et al., 2018): The FFMI is used to measure Machiavellianism. It uses a five-point Likert scale that ranges from “Disagree strongly” to “Agree strongly”. The FFMI contains 52 items. 

3. Narcissistic Personality Inventory – 16 (NPI-16; Ames et al., 2006): The NPI-16 is a shortened form of the NPI-40 for measuring subclinical narcissism. The NPI-16 consists of 16 item pairs selected from the 40 item pairs found in the NPI-40. 

4. The Big Five Inventory (BFI; John & Srivastava, 1999): The BFI is a self-report inventory that measure the Big Five dimensions. It contains a total of 44 items total, and consists of short phrases that participants must rate on a five-point Likert scale which ranges from “Disagree Strongly” to “Agree Strongly”.

Conflict Tactics 
Revised Conflict Tactics Scale short form (CTS2S; Straus & Douglas, 2004): The CTS2S is a shortened version of the revised Conflict Tactic Scale (CTS2). The CTS2S measures intimate partner violence, assessing negotiation, physical assault, and psychological aggression. Contains 20 items that describe IPV scenarios accompanied with an six-point Likert scale that ranges from ”once in the past year” to “more than 20 times in the past year”. On the scale participants can select 7 for “Not in the past year, but it did happen before” or 8 for “This has never happened”.

References:

Ames, Daniel R., Rose, Paul, and Anderson, Cameron P. (2006). The NPI-16 as a short measure of narcissism. Journal of Research in Personality, 40, 440-450.

Collison, K. L., Vize, C. E., Miller, J. D., & Lynam, D. R. (2018). Development and preliminary validation of a five factor model measure of Machiavellianism. Psychological Assessment, 30(10), 1401–1407. https://doi.org/10.1037/pas0000637

John, O. P., & Srivastava, S. (1999). The Big-Five trait taxonomy: History, measurement, and theoretical perspectives. In L.A. Pervin & O. P. John (Eds.), Handbook of personality: Theory and research (Vol. 2, pp. 102–138). New York: Guilford Press.

Paulhus D, Neumann CS, Hare RD. Manual for the self‐report of psychopathy (SRP) scale. Toronto, ON: Multi‐Health Systems, (in press).

Strauss, M. A., & Douglas, E. M. (2004). Short Form of the Revised Conflict Tactics Scales, and Typologies for Severity and Mutuality. Violence and Victims, 19(5), 507-520.

Multiple linear regression will be used the test each of the following models:
Model 1: Controls (n = 2; gender and age) + FFM (n = 5; neuroticism, agreeableness, conscientiousness, extraversion, and openness)
Model 2: Controls (n = 2) + FFM (n = 5) + SRP4:SF facets (n = 4; interpersonal, affective, lifestyle, antisocial)
Model 3: Controls (n = 2) + FFM (n = 5) + NPI-16 total (n = 1)
Model 4: Controls (n = 2) + FFM (n = 5) + FFMI factors (n = 3; antagonism, agency, and planfulness)

Descriptive statistics (means, standard deviations, internal consistency coefficients) and all inter-correlations between the variables will be calculated. 
Carton and Egan (2017) reported that many of their variables were significantly and positively skewed. Preliminary tests of normality will be calculated for all of the tested predictors and the two outcomes (perpetration/ victimization). Square root and log transformations will be attempted on any variables that deviate from normality. If such transformations do not solve non-normality, non-parametric tests will be utilized. 

We will also be calculating internal consistency statistics for each scale (Cronbach’s alpha). Any scale with an alpha less than .60 will not be included in the analyses. Therefore, if the subscales do not show adequate internal consistency, then total scores will be used instead in the analyses. For the SRP:4SF, if the individual facets show poor internal consistency we will use Factor 1 (Interpersonal/Affective) and Factor 2 (Lifestyle/Behavioural). If Factor 1 or Factor 2 show poor internal consistency, we will use total scores.

Question 1: What is the relationship between the FFM of personality and both the perpetration and victimization of Intimate Partner Violence (IPV), while controlling for age and gender?

Hypothesis 1: After controlling for gender and age, agreeableness will be significantly and negatively related to both the perpetration and victimization of IPV (measured by the CTS2S). This hypothesis is based on the findings from Carton and Egan (2017).
Analysis: A multiple linear regression analysis will be conducted. The two control variables (age and gender) and the FFM will be entered into the same block. 

Question 2: What is the relationship between psychopathy and both the perpetration and victimization of Intimate Partner Violence (IPV), while controlling for age, gender, and the FFM?
Hypothesis 2: Psychopathy will be significantly related to both the perpetration and victimization of IPV.  More specifically, the affective facet will show the largest relationships with IPV.
Analysis: A multiple linear regression analysis will be conducted. The two control variables (age and gender) and the FFM will be entered into the same block. The four psychopathy facets will then be entered into Block 2 to assess the incremental relationship between the psychopathy facets and IPV. 

Question 3: What is the relationship between narcissism and both the perpetration and victimization of Intimate Partner Violence (IPV), while controlling for age, gender, and the FFM?

Hypothesis 3: Narcissism will be significantly related to both the perpetration and victimization of IPV.
Analysis: A multiple linear regression analysis will be conducted. The two control variables (age and gender) and the FFM will be entered into the same block. The total narcissism score will then be entered into Block 2 to assess the incremental relationship between narcissism and IPV.
Question 4: What is the relationship between Machiavellianism and both the perpetration and victimization of Intimate Partner Violence (IPV), while controlling for age, gender, and the FFM?

Hypothesis: Given that several studies have linked Machiavellianism to sexual coercion (e.g., Jonason & Kavanagh, 2010) and that others have not found relationships between Machiavellianism and IPV (e.g., Kiire, 2017) and that Carton and Egan did not find relationships between MACH and the CTS, it was predicted that the facets of agency and planfulness of the FFMI would not be related to the perpetration or victimization of IPV. The antagonism facet, however, was predicted to be related to perpetration and victimization of IPV.
Analysis: A multiple linear regression analysis will be conducted. The two control variables (age and gender) and the FFM will be entered into the same block. The three FFMI facets will then be entered into Block 2 to assess the incremental relationship between the FFMI facets and IPV.

2. Five Factor Machiavellianism Inventory (FFMI; Collison et al., 2018): The FFMI is used to measure Machiavellianism. It uses a five-point Likert scale that ranges from “Disagree strongly” to “Agree strongly”. The FFMI contains 52 items. 

3. Narcissistic Personality Inventory – 16 (NPI-16; Ames et al., 2006): The NPI-16 is a shortened form of the NPI-40 for measuring subclinical narcissism. The NPI-16 consists of 16 item pairs selected from the 40 item pairs found in the NPI-40. 

4. The Big Five Inventory (BFI; John & Srivastava, 1999): The BFI is a self-report inventory that measure the Big Five dimensions. It contains a total of 44 items total, and consists of short phrases that participants must rate on a five-point Likert scale which ranges from “Disagree Strongly” to “Agree Strongly”.

Conflict Tactics 
Revised Conflict Tactics Scale short form (CTS2S; Straus & Douglas, 2004): The CTS2S is a shortened version of the revised Conflict Tactic Scale (CTS2). The CTS2S measures intimate partner violence, assessing negotiation, physical assault, and psychological aggression. Contains 20 items that describe IPV scenarios accompanied with an six-point Likert scale that ranges from ”once in the past year” to “more than 20 times in the past year”. On the scale participants can select 7 for “Not in the past year, but it did happen before” or 8 for “This has never happened”.

References:

Ames, Daniel R., Rose, Paul, and Anderson, Cameron P. (2006). The NPI-16 as a short measure of narcissism. Journal of Research in Personality, 40, 440-450.

Collison, K. L., Vize, C. E., Miller, J. D., & Lynam, D. R. (2018). Development and preliminary validation of a five factor model measure of Machiavellianism. Psychological Assessment, 30(10), 1401–1407. https://doi.org/10.1037/pas0000637

John, O. P., & Srivastava, S. (1999). The Big-Five trait taxonomy: History, measurement, and theoretical perspectives. In L.A. Pervin & O. P. John (Eds.), Handbook of personality: Theory and research (Vol. 2, pp. 102–138). New York: Guilford Press.

Paulhus D, Neumann CS, Hare RD. Manual for the self‐report of psychopathy (SRP) scale. Toronto, ON: Multi‐Health Systems, (in press).

Strauss, M. A., & Douglas, E. M. (2004). Short Form of the Revised Conflict Tactics Scales, and Typologies for Severity and Mutuality. Violence and Victims, 19(5), 507-520.
registration_responses.q19.question:
Multiple linear regression will be used the test each of the following models:
Model 1: Controls (n = 2; gender and age) + FFM (n = 5; neuroticism, agreeableness, conscientiousness, extraversion, and openness)
Model 2: Controls (n = 2) + FFM (n = 5) + SRP4:SF facets (n = 4; interpersonal, affective, lifestyle, antisocial)
Model 3: Controls (n = 2) + FFM (n = 5) + NPI-16 total (n = 1)
Model 4: Controls (n = 2) + FFM (n = 5) + FFMI factors (n = 3; antagonism, agency, and planfulness)

Descriptive statistics (means, standard deviations, internal consistency coefficients) and all inter-correlations between the variables will be calculated. 
Carton and Egan (2017) reported that many of their variables were significantly and positively skewed. Preliminary tests of normality will be calculated for all of the tested predictors and the two outcomes (perpetration/ victimization). Square root and log transformations will be attempted on any variables that deviate from normality. If such transformations do not solve non-normality, non-parametric tests will be utilized. 

We will also be calculating internal consistency statistics for each scale (Cronbach’s alpha). Any scale with an alpha less than .60 will not be included in the analyses. Therefore, if the subscales do not show adequate internal consistency, then total scores will be used instead in the analyses. For the SRP:4SF, if the individual facets show poor internal consistency we will use Factor 1 (Interpersonal/Affective) and Factor 2 (Lifestyle/Behavioural). If Factor 1 or Factor 2 show poor internal consistency, we will use total scores.

Question 1: What is the relationship between the FFM of personality and both the perpetration and victimization of Intimate Partner Violence (IPV), while controlling for age and gender?

Hypothesis 1: After controlling for gender and age, agreeableness will be significantly and negatively related to both the perpetration and victimization of IPV (measured by the CTS2S). This hypothesis is based on the findings from Carton and Egan (2017).
Analysis: A multiple linear regression analysis will be conducted. The two control variables (age and gender) and the FFM will be entered into the same block. 

Question 2: What is the relationship between psychopathy and both the perpetration and victimization of Intimate Partner Violence (IPV), while controlling for age, gender, and the FFM?
Hypothesis 2: Psychopathy will be significantly related to both the perpetration and victimization of IPV.  More specifically, the affective facet will show the largest relationships with IPV.
Analysis: A multiple linear regression analysis will be conducted. The two control variables (age and gender) and the FFM will be entered into the same block. The four psychopathy facets will then be entered into Block 2 to assess the incremental relationship between the psychopathy facets and IPV. 

Question 3: What is the relationship between narcissism and both the perpetration and victimization of Intimate Partner Violence (IPV), while controlling for age, gender, and the FFM?

Hypothesis 3: Narcissism will be significantly related to both the perpetration and victimization of IPV.
Analysis: A multiple linear regression analysis will be conducted. The two control variables (age and gender) and the FFM will be entered into the same block. The total narcissism score will then be entered into Block 2 to assess the incremental relationship between narcissism and IPV.
Question 4: What is the relationship between Machiavellianism and both the perpetration and victimization of Intimate Partner Violence (IPV), while controlling for age, gender, and the FFM?

Hypothesis: Given that several studies have linked Machiavellianism to sexual coercion (e.g., Jonason & Kavanagh, 2010) and that others have not found relationships between Machiavellianism and IPV (e.g., Kiire, 2017) and that Carton and Egan did not find relationships between MACH and the CTS, it was predicted that the facets of agency and planfulness of the FFMI would not be related to the perpetration or victimization of IPV. The antagonism facet, however, was predicted to be related to perpetration and victimization of IPV.
Analysis: A multiple linear regression analysis will be conducted. The two control variables (age and gender) and the FFM will be entered into the same block. The three FFMI facets will then be entered into Block 2 to assess the incremental relationship between the FFMI facets and IPV.

attributes.title: Optimization of the mouse Light/dark box test: effect of light intensity and test duration on behavioural outcomes

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Optimization of the mouse Light/dark box test: effect of light intensity and test duration on behavioural outcomes

other.value: i) number of urination events, ii) number of fecal boli, iii) number of rearings, iv) number of grooming events, v) number of jumps, vi) duration of freezing will be recorded and potentially analysed in the exploratory part of the study.

sample.value: A total of 32 animals across two strains (C57BL/6 and Swiss) and both sexes (n=4 per strain and sex) will be tested. 8 animals (n=2 per sex and strain) will be used in the pilot study and 24 animals (n=6 per stain and sex) will be used in the main experiment. The sample size was calculated in a power calculation using a one-tailed t-test corrected for multiple testing.

analyses.value: To analyse the behavioural outcomes, we will use generalized linear models with light intensity and test duration as fixed effects, and cage (with 2 mice per cage) as a random effect. Regarding the exploratory part of the study, we will analyse the correlations between test outcomes and home cage behavioural patterns.

outliers.value: We will exclude animals which die or develop signs of seriously impaired welfare (e.g. pain, sickness, weight loss, according to pre-specified humane endpoints) that could bias the experimental outcomes. Animals that die before the start of the experiment will be replaced. No further observations will be excluded.

dependent.value:
The dependent variables in the Light/Dark box will be: i) time spent in the two compartments, and ii) number of transitions between the two compartments.
Each animal will be tested three times for a period of 15 minutes in the Light/dark box under three different light conditions. Animals will be video recorded during testing and outcome measures will be extracted in a subsequent video analysis. In addition, all animals will be video recorded in their home cage across three days during testing period, for 12 hours each day, during the dark (active) phase. Appropriate sampling time will be chosen after a pilot in which home-cage recordings of individuals (n = 3) who showed more extreme phenotypic responses in the Light/Dark box will be scanned. This will allow to define the sampling periods for all the animals. Frequencies or durations of the following behaviours will be measured: i) stereotypies (bar-mouthing, circling, back-flipping, twirling, jumping), ii) eating, iii) drinking, iv) unprotected and protected rearing, v) self- and allo-grooming, vi) aggressive interaction, vi) anogenital exploration, vii) nest building, viii) burrowing. Correlations between these measures and behavioural test outcomes will be investigated.

conditions.value: Each animal will be tested under three different light conditions (dark: 4lux; medium: intensity will be defined based on a pilot study; bright: 700lux) for a period of 15 minutes. The order of testing light conditions will be counter-balanced for each animal. The pilot study will follow the same procedure as the one described for testing. The effect of test duration will be analysed by comparing different time frames (3 mins vs. 5mins vs. 10mins vs. 15mins) within the test duration.

hypothesis.value: How do light intensity and test duration affect behavioural outcomes of mice in the Light/Dark box?
